title: FUN WITH TRAFFIC LIGHTS
historical_context: This article reflects the hacker culture of the late 1980s, where pranks and subverting public infrastructure were seen as forms of rebellion and exploration of technology.
target_audience: Hackers, pranksters, and those interested in the subversion of public systems.
short_summary: This article provides a guide on how to manipulate traffic lights for amusement, detailing methods to switch lights manually and cause accidents. It emphasizes a reckless approach to hacking public infrastructure.
summary:
In 'FUN WITH TRAFFIC LIGHTS', Dial Tone presents a provocative guide on how to tamper with traffic lights, showcasing a blend of technical knowledge and a disregard for public safety. The article begins with a tongue-in-cheek disclaimer about the author's affiliations and quickly dives into the mechanics of traffic light systems. Readers are instructed to locate the control boxes of traffic lights and manipulate their settings, turning them from automatic to manual and causing chaos on the roads. The author encourages readers to engage in dangerous pranks, highlighting a culture of thrill-seeking and anti-establishment attitudes prevalent among hackers of the time.

The narrative is laced with dark humor and a sense of rebellion, reflecting the ethos of the Cult of the Dead Cow (cDc). Dial Tone's writing style is unapologetic and confrontational, as he dismisses any potential backlash with a flippant attitude. The article serves as both a cautionary tale and a celebration of the hacker spirit, emphasizing the allure of subverting public systems for personal amusement. While the techniques described are technically intriguing, they also raise ethical questions about the responsibilities of those who possess such knowledge.
